questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

 

In a patient with renal insufficiency and low urine output, the preferred antihypertensive medication would be one that is safe in renal failure.

 

Amlodipine is a good choice because it is a calcium channel blocker that does not affect renal function. Although it can cause pedal edema in some patients but the pedal edema which is given in the question seems to be due to renal insufficiency itself. The adverse effect of pedal edema does not make it contra-indicated for hypertension.  It also has a long duration of action and is well-tolerated in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor that can lead to severe hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with renal insufficiency. Hyperkalemia can exacerbate renal dysfunction and pose serious health risks, making aliskiren an unsuitable choice for this patient.

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic. Thiazide diuretics are typically ineffective in patients with significantly impaired renal function (e.g., low GFR) and can cause electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia and hyponatremia. Therefore, chlorthalidone is not recommended for patients with renal insufficiency and low urine output.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker used to lower blood pressure. However, it is not typically a first-line drug for hypertension due to its side effects, such as postural hypotension. Additionally, prazosin can cause fluid retention, which may worsen renal function in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amlodipine is the preferred antihypertensive medication for patients with renal insufficiency, as it effectively lowers blood pressure without negatively impacting renal function.

choices.text: Increase dose of haloperidol
Change haloperidol to clozapine
Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol

questions.text: A patient of Schizophrenia was started on antipsychotic drug haloperidol. Few hours later, he presented with torticollis and muscular dystonia. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Give benztropine

 

When a patient on haloperidol develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like torticollis and muscular dystonia, the next best step is typically to administer an anticholinergic medication like benzhexol or benztropine to alleviate these side effects. Increasing the dose of haloperidol would likely worsen the EPS, while changing to clozapine is an option for patients with severe EPS or a history of non-response to other treatments. Fluphenazine is unlikely to be significantly different from haloperidol in causing EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of haloperidol: Increasing the dose of haloperidol is not the appropriate response when a patient develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as torticollis and muscular dystonia. It can exacerbate these side effects.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less likely to cause EPS compared to typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Switching to clozapine can be a reasonable option to manage EPS.

 

Option C. Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol: Fluphenazine is another typical antipsychotic and is not expected to be significantly different from haloperidol in terms of causing EPS. Switching to fluphenazine may not effectively address the EPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to manage extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications. It can be an appropriate choice to alleviate the torticollis and muscular dystonia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the hospital by their parents with symptoms of squint and diminished vision. For conducting refraction testing on this child, which of the following drugs would be most suitable? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1% Atropine

 

1% Atropine is the most suitable drug for refraction testing in a child with squint and diminished vision. Atropine is used as a cycloplegic agent to paralyze the ciliary muscle of the eye, enabling accurate measurement of refractive error, especially in children where accommodative spasm can interfere with the results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. 1% Tropicamide: Although tropicamide is also a mydriatic and cycloplegic agent, its cycloplegic action is less pronounced than atropine. As a child is likely to have higher tone of ciliary muscle, it is not reliable drug for cycloplegic action in children.

 

Option B. 0.5% Loteprednol: This is a corticosteroid used for inflammation, not appropriate for refraction testing.

 

Option D. 0.5% Timolol: A beta-blocker used for glaucoma treatment, not suitable for pupil dilation or refraction testing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1% Atropine is the most effective cycloplegic agent for refraction testing in children, providing reliable and accurate measurement of refractive error by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing accommodation.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinidine

 

Quinidine is a Class Ia anti arrhythmic drug that acts by blocking Na+ channels as well as K+ channels. It can lead to prolonged QT interval and Torsades de pointes. Flecainide, Encainide and Propafenone are other drugs that belong to Class Ic antiarrhythmics and can also precipitate Torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks sodium channels. It does not significantly affect the QT interval and is not associated with QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Magnesium sulfate: Magnesium sulfate is used to treat Torsades de Pointes and other arrhythmias but does not cause QT prolongation. In fact, it is often administered to help stabilize the cardiac electrical activity in cases of prolonged QT interval.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because neither lignocaine nor magnesium sulfate is associated with QT prolongation. Only quinidine is known to cause QT prolongation among the listed drugs.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Class Ia Antiarrhythmics: These drugs, including quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide, are known to prolong the QT interval by blocking both Na+ and K+ channels.
  • Class Ic Antiarrhythmics: Drugs like flecainide, encainide, and propafenone can also precipitate Torsades de Pointes, although their primary action is on Na+ channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinidine, a Class Ia antiarrhythmic drug, is associated with QT prolongation and can lead to Torsades de Pointes due to its action on both sodium and potassium channels.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The given image shows a hydatid cyst in the liver. Large, unilocular/multilocular, well-defined, hypodense cysts. Contains multiple internal “daughter” cysts of lower density than “mother” cyst (exocyst). Curvilinear ring-like calcification of pericyst (wall).

 

Causative organism – Echinococcus granulosus

 

Definitive hosts – Dogs, Intermediate host – Sheep, Accidental intermediate host – Human (end stage host)

 

In the liver, the pressure effect of the cyst can produce symptoms of obstructive jaundice and abdominal pain. With biliary rupture, the classic triad of biliary colic, jaundice, and urticaria is observed. Passage of hydatid membranes in the emesis (hydatid emesia) and passage of membranes in the stools (hydatid enterica) may occur rarely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma japonicum: This parasitic worm causes schistosomiasis, primarily affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: This protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and digestive system, not forming cysts in the liver.

 

Option D. Schistosoma mansoni: This parasitic worm also causes schistosomiasis, affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

 

This option is not a standard practice when transporting conscious polytrauma patients. Shifting a conscious patient to a lateral position and immediately moving them can risk further injury and discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strap his thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher: This is a common and necessary practice when transporting a conscious polytrauma patient. It helps secure the patient to the stretcher to prevent movement and further injury during transport.

 

Option B. Apply a cervical collar: This is done to immobilize the cervical spine, till a cervical injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. Roll the patient and put on a hardboard: Rolling a conscious polytrauma patient and placing them on a hardboard (spinal board) can be a part of the standard protocol for immobilizing the spine and minimizing movement during transport. This is done to prevent potential spinal cord injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.

 

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

 

The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

choices.text: The efficacy of the drug b and c are equal
Drug A is the most potent drug
Drug C is less potent and equally efficacious to drug B
Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B, and equally efficacious as drug C

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B and equally efficacious as drug C

 

The above given image is that of a Log Dose-Response curve, where on the X axis we plot the Log concentration of the drug and on the Y axis we plot the Response. From this type of curve , we can know about the following 3 parameters about a drug:

 

  • Potency – Potency means the power of a drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.

  • Efficacy – It is the maximum response produced by a drug. The maximum height of the curve corresponds to the efficacy, or in other words, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug becomes.

  • Safety – The slope of the curve is related to the safety of the drug. The drug with a steeper slope is less safe than a drug with a flatter slope.

 

In the given graph:

 

Potency: D > A > B > C

 

Efficacy: A = B > C = D

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The efficacy of both drugs A and B are equal and the efficacy of drugs D and C are equal.

 

Option B. Drug D is the most potent drug

 

Option C. Drug C is less potent but equally efficacious to drug D

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the given Log Dose-Response curve, Drug D is the most potent drug but is less efficacious than drugs A and B, and equally efficacious as drug C. Potency is determined by the position of the curve along the X-axis, while efficacy is determined by the maximum height of the curve.

choices.text: The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual.
The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects.
The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.
The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients.

questions.text: Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50). Both LD50 and ED50 are calculated by checking different doses in a population.

 

  • It represents the margin of safety of a drug. A higher Clinical Therapeutic Index indicates that a drug has a greater margin of safety, and can be given at higher doses without causing significant adverse effects.
  • The Clinical Therapeutic Index is an important consideration in the development and use of new medications, and helps healthcare providers determine the appropriate dose for individual patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual: This description is incorrect because the therapeutic index is determined based on population data, not individual data.

 

Option B. The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects: This describes the therapeutic window or therapeutic range, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients: This is a general description of an effective and safe dosage regimen but does not specifically describe the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50) in a population, representing the drug's margin of safety. A higher Therapeutic Index indicates a greater margin of safety.

questions.text: Most commonly implicated drug for idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxicillin-clavulanate

 

Explanation:


Idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury (DILI) occurs unpredictably and is unrelated to drug dose or duration. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is one of the most common causes of idiosyncratic DILI globally, often manifesting as a cholestatic or mixed pattern of liver injury. It is distinct from dose-dependent liver injury, such as that caused by paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: Valproate-induced liver injury is typically idiosyncratic but less frequent than amoxicillin-clavulanate. Risk factors include young age and polytherapy with other antiepileptic drugs.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin rarely causes hepatotoxicity and is not a common cause of DILI. Its primary concerns relate to bleeding due to its anticoagulant effects.

 

Option D. Paracetamol: Paracetamol is the leading cause of dose-dependent acute liver failure, not idiosyncratic DILI. Its toxicity is related to overdose or risk factors such as pre-existing liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a leading cause of idiosyncratic drug-induced liver injury, presenting unpredictably and often unrelated to dose or duration. This is distinct from dose-dependent hepatotoxicity like that caused by paracetamol.

choices.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

Enteric coatings on tablets protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and deliver drugs distal to the stomach. However, they do not prolong the half-life of a drug, which is determined by the drug's metabolism and elimination from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Enteric-coated drugs are designed with a special coating that resists dissolution in the acidic environment of the stomach. This coating dissolves instead in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine. The primary purposes of this enteric coating are:

 

Option A. Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: Some drugs are unstable in the acidic environment of the stomach and can be degraded before they have a chance to be absorbed. Enteric coating protects these drugs from the acidic gastric environment, ensuring they reach the intestine, where they can be absorbed effectively.

 

Option B. Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs: Certain drugs can irritate the gastric mucosa, leading to discomfort or even ulcers. Enteric coating prevents these drugs from being released in the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of gastric irritation.

 

Option D. Deliver drugs distal to the stomach: Enteric coating is also used to ensure that a drug is released in the intestine rather than the stomach, which can be important for drugs that are intended to act in the intestine or are better absorbed from the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following is a fifth-generation cephalosporin active against MRSA? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Ceftaroline

 

Explanation:

 

Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin specifically designed to be active against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It differs from other cephalosporins by its ability to bind to the altered penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) expressed in MRSA, particularly PBP2a, which confers methicillin resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Ceftolozane - This is not a fifth-generation cephalosporin with anti-MRSA activity. Ceftolozane is typically combined with tazobactam and has activity primarily against gram-negative bacteria including Pseudomonas.
  • Option C. Cefpirome - Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin without specific activity against MRSA.
  • Option D. Ceftizoxime - This is a third-generation cephalosporin without activity against MRSA.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fifth-generation cephalosporins such as ceftaroline are distinguished by their ability to bind to altered PBPs in MRSA, making them effective against this resistant organism that is typically not susceptible to other β-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures. On examination, blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

This case presents a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy, as indicated by the symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, along with severely elevated blood pressure (220/110 mmHg). In hypertensive emergencies, the goal is to rapidly reduce blood pressure using intravenous medications to prevent further organ damage.

 

IV Labetalol is a preferred treatment in hypertensive emergencies, especially those involving encephalopathy. Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker that can reduce blood pressure quickly and effectively, making it ideal for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Nifedipine: Oral nifedipine is not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies because it does not act rapidly enough, and oral medications are generally avoided in such acute settings.

 

Option B. Oral Nicardipine capsules: Like oral nifedipine, oral nicardipine is not suitable for emergencies due to its slower onset of action. Nicardipine is more effective in its intravenous form for such cases.

 

Option C. IV Nitroglycerine: Although IV nitroglycerine can be used in hypertensive emergencies, it is not the best choice for hypertensive encephalopathy. Nitroglycerine is more commonly used in cases involving acute coronary syndromes or pulmonary edema, but it is usually avoided in patients with CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for Hypertensive emergencies:

 

  • Encephalopathy - Nicardipine or IV Labetalol

  • Intracranial Hemorrhage - Nicardipine or Labetalol

  • Acute Coronary Syndrome – IV Nitroglycerin

  • Pulmonary Edema - Intravenous Nitroglycerin / Sodium Nitroprusside

  • Aortic Dissection – Nicardipine in combination with Esmolol or Labetalol

  • In Pregnancy - Labetalol

choices.text: Adequate safety profile needs to be established
Cost to benefit has to be considered
Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the selection of essential drugs? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

 

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (Drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population. They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness. Essential medicines are intended to be available within the context of functioning health systems at all times and in adequate amounts, in appropriate dosage forms, with assured quality and adequate information, and at a price the individual and the community can afford.”

 

This is generally false. While fixed-dose combinations (FDCs) can be beneficial in certain scenarios (like in the treatment of HIV/AIDS or tuberculosis), they are not universally preferred over single-drug formulations. The preference for FDCs or single drugs depends on several factors, including the therapeutic context, the risk of drug-drug interactions, patient adherence, and the potential for resistance development. Mostly, single drugs are preferred due to their flexibility in dosing and the ability to adjust individual components based on patient needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate safety profile needs to be established: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, it's crucial that they have a well-established safety profile. Safety is a key consideration to ensure that the benefits of a drug outweigh its risks.

 

Option B. Cost to benefit has to be considered: This is also true. In the selection of essential drugs, the cost-effectiveness of a drug is an important factor. The aim is to provide the most effective treatment at the lowest possible cost.

 

Option D. Disease prevalence is considered: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, the prevalence of diseases in a population is an important consideration. Drugs to treat common and life-threatening diseases are typically prioritized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The selection of essential drugs prioritizes factors like safety, cost-effectiveness, and disease prevalence. Fixed-dose combinations are not universally preferred over single drugs, as the choice depends on specific therapeutic needs and other considerations.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peptic ulcer disease

 

The M1 muscarinic receptors in the stomach increase the acid secretion. Pirenzepine is an M1 blocker, which can help in reducing the acid secretion and thereby was used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma is typically treated with bronchodilators (e.g., beta-agonists) and anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., corticosteroids). Pirenzepine is not used in the treatment of asthma.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is often treated with medications that reduce intraocular pressure, such as beta-blockers, prostaglandin analogs, or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. Pirenzepine is not indicated for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Hypertension is treated with a variety of medications including diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and others. Pirenzepine is not used in the management of hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pirenzepine is an M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist that reduces gastric acid secretion and is used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated for conditions such as asthma, glaucoma, or hypertension.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

choices.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add-on drug to lithium
Thiazides increase the tubular resorption of lithium
Thiazides cause water loss thereby increasing lithium levels

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of bipolar disorder has been stable on lithium therapy. Recently, he was diagnosed with hypertension and started on thiazide diuretics. After a few days, he presented with coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. What is the likely mechanism of this interaction between lithium and thiazides? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiazides increase the tubular resorption of lithium

 

Thiazides reduce the excretion of sodium in the renal tubules. Lithium is reabsorbed in a manner similar to sodium, leading to its increased reabsorption and elevated blood levels, resulting in potential toxicity. In this clinical case, the patient's symptoms of lithium toxicity are most likely due to the thiazide-induced increase in tubular reabsorption of lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium: Lithium is primarily excreted unchanged by the kidneys, not metabolized. Thiazides don't affect lithium's metabolism.

 

Option B. Thiazides act as an add-on drug to lithium: There's no evidence that thiazides synergistically increase the toxic or therapeutic effects of lithium.

 

Option D. Thiazides cause water loss thereby increasing lithium levels: Thiazides do act as diuretics, but the primary mechanism of increasing lithium levels is through enhanced tubular reabsorption rather than water loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium, leading to elevated blood levels and potential toxicity. This interaction is crucial to consider when prescribing thiazides to patients on lithium therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female victim of RTA presents to the ER. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen is soft. The probable diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, tympanic note (hyper-resonant) on percussion, and decreased breath sounds on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure in the chest cavity. This condition can compress the lungs and the great vessels in the chest, causing respiratory distress, hypotension, elevated JVP, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Tympanic percussion note over the right chest is consistent with air in the pleural space. Ecchymosis (bruising) over the chest wall can result from trauma and rib fractures associated with tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with symptoms such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins (Jugular Venous Pressure - JVP). While elevated JVP is mentioned in the scenario, the other symptoms associated with cardiac tamponade, such as muffled heart sounds and hypotension, are not present.

 

Option C. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion involves the accumulation of fluid around the heart. While it can cause elevated JVP, it typically presents with other cardiac symptoms, such as muffled heart sounds and chest pain. The scenario does not mention these cardiac-specific symptoms.

 

Option D. Massive hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to a significant accumulation of blood in the pleural space. It can cause decreased breath sounds, but it is not typically associated with a tympanic percussion note or elevated JVP unless there is concurrent tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately causes collapse of the affected lung.

 

It is characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment must never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. Management includes:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an inhibitor of ATP binding cassette efflux pumps? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Verapamil

 

Verapamil is known to inhibit the activity of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters, such as P-glycoprotein, which is one of the most well-studied drug efflux transporters. By inhibiting P-glycoprotein, verapamil can increase the intracellular concentration of various drugs, which is why it is sometimes used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer to improve drug absorption and decrease drug clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug used mainly after allogeneic organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and lower the risk of organ rejection. It is not an inhibitor of the ATP-binding cassette efflux transporters.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat hypertension and angina pectoris. It is not known to inhibit ABC efflux transporters.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem, like verapamil, is a calcium channel blocker, but it is not as potent as verapamil in inhibiting P-glycoprotein. However, it does have some effect on drug efflux transporters, but to a lesser extent compared to verapamil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil is a known inhibitor of ATP-binding cassette transporters, particularly P-glycoprotein, and can be used to enhance the pharmacokinetics of various drugs by increasing their intracellular concentrations.

questions.text:
Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs, whereas diazepam is a basic drug. Which of the following statement/s about these drugs is/are true? (Twisted PYQ)

  1. Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach and thus poorly absorbed.
  2. Diazepam is absorbed from the stomach due to its high lipid solubility.
  3. Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area.
  4. Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine, although to a lesser extent than the small intestine.
  5. Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs, like diarrhea, will decrease drug absorption in the small intestine.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3, 4 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

The absorption of drugs depends on the non-ionized, lipid-soluble form of the drug, which crosses membranes more efficiently.

  1. Phenobarbitone absorption occurs mainly in the small intestine due to its large surface area (True): Like most drugs, phenobarbitone absorption is maximized in the small intestine, where the surface area for absorption is far greater than in the stomach.
  2. Drugs can be absorbed in the large intestine (True): Although the surface area of the large intestine is smaller than that of the small intestine, it can still absorb drugs. This is particularly relevant for sustained-release formulations or drugs undergoing enterohepatic recycling.
  3. Diseases decreasing transit time (True): Conditions like diarrhea reduce the time available for drug absorption in the intestine, leading to reduced absorption.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

  • Aspirin is mostly ionized in the stomach (False): Aspirin, an acidic drug, remains largely non-ionized in the stomach and is capable of being absorbed there. However, its absorption is limited due to the short gastric emptying time.
  • Diazepam is absorbed in the stomach (False): Diazepam, a basic drug, becomes non-ionized in the alkaline pH of the intestine, where its lipid solubility facilitates maximal absorption.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug absorption depends on the physicochemical properties of the drug (acidic or basic), the pH of the gastrointestinal tract, and the surface area available. Most absorption occurs in the small intestine due to its large surface area, irrespective of the drug's acidic or basic nature. Transit time significantly impacts absorption, with shorter times, such as in diarrhea, reducing drug absorption.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-blockers is contraindicated in patients with congestive heart failure due to its intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pindolol

 

Explanation:


Pindolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). Beta-blockers with ISA are generally contraindicated in heart failure as they can stimulate beta receptors, counteracting the benefits of beta blockade. This can increase myocardial workload and exacerbate heart failure, making pindolol unsuitable for these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker but lacks ISA. While it is not preferred in heart failure management, it is not contraindicated like pindolol.

 

Option B. Bisoprolol: Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker approved for use in heart failure. It decreases mortality by reducing sympathetic activation and improving heart function.

 

Option D. Carvedilol: Carvedilol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking effects. It is highly effective in CHF management and has been proven to reduce mortality.

 

Educational Objective:


Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, such as pindolol, are contraindicated in heart failure due to their ability to increase myocardial workload. Preferred beta-blockers for CHF management include bisoprolol, carvedilol, and metoprolol, which reduce mortality by improving cardiac function and limiting sympathetic overdrive.

questions.text: Sacubitril is a new drug approved for chronic heart failure. The mechanism of action of Sacubitril is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

 

Sacubitril is a Neprilysin inhibitor (Neutral Endopeptidase inhibitor). Neprilysin is the enzyme that metabolizes Atrial Natriuretic Peptide, Substance P, Bradykinin, Adrenomedullin and Angiotensin II. It is used in a 1:1 ratio with Valsartan (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker), thereby increasing the levels of the other substances which helps in decreasing the blood pressure in a patient of chronic heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiotensin II inhibitor: Sacubitril does not directly inhibit angiotensin II. However, valsartan, which is combined with sacubitril in the fixed-dose combination, blocks the effects of angiotensin II at its receptor.

 

Option B. ACE inhibitor: Sacubitril is not an ACE inhibitor. ACE inhibitors work by inhibiting the angiotensin-converting enzyme, which decreases the production of angiotensin II. Sacubitril, on the other hand, inhibits neprilysin.

 

Option C. Renin inhibitor: Sacubitril is not a renin inhibitor. Renin inhibitors, such as aliskiren, work by directly inhibiting renin, an enzyme involved in the RAAS pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacubitril is a neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor used in combination with valsartan to treat chronic heart failure. By inhibiting neprilysin, sacubitril increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and other vasoactive substances, leading to beneficial cardiovascular effects.

choices.text: Causes monofollicular development
Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH
Causes endometrial thinning
Can be used with gonadotropins

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding clomiphene citrate? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Causes monofollicular development
 

  • Clomiphene citrate is SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) that inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which in turn leads to an increase in LH/FSH, and this helps in the development of multiple follicles in the ovary. Clomiphene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility.
  • Due to its anti-estrogenic action over the endometrium, it causes thickening of the cervical mucus and thinning of the endometrium.
  • Sometimes for ovulation induction, gonadotropins can be used with clomiphene, but it has a risk of giving rise to multiple pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

questions.text: A pregnant female in first trimester developed deep vein thrombosis. She requires anticoagulation. Which of the following will be the preferred drug in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enoxaparin

 

Enoxaparin is the preferred drug for a pregnant female with DVT, particularly in the first trimester. Its safety profile and effectiveness in treating and preventing DVT make it suitable for use in pregnancy. The other options either have safety concerns during pregnancy or are not typically used for the treatment of DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: This is an antiplatelet drug, not typically used in the treatment of DVT, and its safety in pregnancy is not well-established.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and is generally contraindicated in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, due to the risk of teratogenic effects (warfarin embryopathy).

 

Option C. Betrixaban: This is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor. The safety of betrixaban in pregnancy has not been established, and it is generally not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because they do not cross the placenta and thus have a lower risk of fetal harm. Enoxaparin is effective in the treatment and prevention of DVT and is considered safe for use in pregnancy.

questions.text: A person purchased two bottles of alcohol from a local liquor store and subsequently developed symptoms of drowsiness, blurred vision, and ataxia. What is the appropriate antidote for treatment?  (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethyl alcohol

 

Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is the correct antidote in this scenario, where the symptoms of drowsiness, blurred vision, and ataxia suggest methanol poisoning, potentially from adulterated alcohol. Ethanol acts by competing with methanol for the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which slows down the conversion of methanol into its toxic metabolites, formaldehyde and formic acid.

 

Note: Now, the antidote of choice for methanol poisoning is fomepizole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose. It is not effective in methanol poisoning, as the symptoms and underlying toxicological mechanisms are different.

 

Option C. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine and would not be an appropriate antidote for methanol poisoning. In fact, using diazepam in this context could exacerbate central nervous system depression.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in opioid overdose cases. It is not effective against the toxic effects of methanol and would not be appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is used as an antidote in methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, thus preventing the formation of toxic metabolites.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Among the options mentioned above, Rifampicin is the drug that acts by blocking RNA polymerase enzyme. It is one of the 1st line Anti Tubercular and anti-Leprosy drugs. It has the bactericidal effect against the mycobacteria, that are present both intracellularly as well as extracellularly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-Fluorouracil: This is an anticancer drug that primarily inhibits thymidylate synthase, affecting DNA synthesis rather than specifically inhibiting RNA synthesis.

 

Option C. Nitrofurantoin: This drug is primarily used for treating urinary tract infections. It does inhibit bacterial DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis but is not specifically an inhibitor of RNA synthesis alone.

 

Option D. Novobiocin: This antibiotic inhibits DNA gyrase, an enzyme involved in DNA supercoiling, but it does not inhibit RNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

Imipenem is a carbapenem that is broken down by the enzyme dehydropeptidase in the kidney. Cilastatin is therefore administered along with it, which is an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase, thereby it prolongs the action of Imipenem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem is another carbapenem antibiotic, but it is not significantly degraded by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require co-administration with cilastatin.

 

Option C. Cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that is not affected by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require cilastatin for its administration.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic, and its activity is not influenced by renal dehydropeptidase I, thus not requiring cilastatin for its administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cilastatin is specifically administered with imipenem to inhibit renal dehydropeptidase I, preventing the breakdown of imipenem and thereby prolonging its action in the body.

choices.text: Conversion of uric acid to allantoin

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with chronic gout is under consideration for a change in treatment plan due to poor response to conventional therapies like allopurinol and colchicine. The healthcare team is discussing the potential use of pegloticase. What is the mechanism of action of pegloticase?" (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of uric acid to allantoin.

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant uricase enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, which is more soluble and easier to excrete through the kidneys. This action helps to lower high levels of uric acid in patients with chronic gout who have not responded well to conventional therapies such as allopurinol and colchicine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase: This is the mechanism of action for allopurinol, not pegloticase. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which is an enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option C. Increase excretion of uric acid: Some medications like probenecid work by this mechanism to increase the renal excretion of uric acid.

 

Option D. Inhibition of granulocyte migration: Colchicine works through inhibiting granulocyte migration, but pegloticase primarily works by metabolizing uric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegloticase works by converting uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble compound that is easily excreted by the kidneys. This mechanism is distinct from other gout treatments and is particularly useful for patients with refractory chronic gout.

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

 

These medications are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Therefore, women who are planning to conceive should discontinue these medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labetalol: Labetalol is generally safe for use during pregnancy and is a treatment option for hypertension in pregnant women. It is not necessary to discontinue this medication.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers like nifedipine are also generally considered safe during pregnancy and are often used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option D. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa is also considered safe during pregnancy and is commonly used for managing hypertension in this population.

 

Given the woman's intention to conceive, discontinuing Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors would be the most appropriate course of action to protect both her health and that of her future child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

questions.text: A patient presents to ophthalmology clinic with pain in eye. On examination and investigations, it was found to be a case of open angle glaucoma. History of the person reveals that he is also suffering from Bronchial asthma. Which of the following anti glaucoma drug should be avoided in this patient? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Timolol

 

Timolol is a non-selective beta blocker, which means it blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors. In patients with bronchial asthma, the blockade of beta-2 receptors can lead to bronchospasm, a potentially severe and life-threatening condition. Therefore, timolol should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma to prevent exacerbation of their respiratory condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha agonist. It primarily acts on alpha-2 adrenergic receptors and does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects associated with beta blockers. Therefore, it can be safely used in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2α (PGF2) analog. It is the drug of choice for the treatment of primary open angle glaucoma and does not have any bronchoconstrictive properties. It is safe for use in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option D. Brimonidine: Brimonidine is another alpha agonist. Similar to apraclonidine, it acts on alpha-2 adrenergic receptors and does not affect the bronchial smooth muscles. Thus, it is also safe for use in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Timolol, a non-selective beta blocker, should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma due to the risk of precipitating bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-6

 

  • Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits the interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptor. By blocking the IL-6 receptor, tocilizumab interrupts the signaling pathway of IL-6, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response. This is particularly beneficial in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where elevated levels of IL-6 contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • Tocilizumab has also been used in COVID-19 for cytokine release syndrome.
  • It is avoided in patients with liver disease, immunosuppression, having a high risk of GIT perforation, Absolute Neutrophil Count <500 cell/µl and Platelet count <50000 cells/µl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IL-2: Drugs like basiliximab or daclizumab are used to target IL-2 receptors.

 

Option C. IL-4: Dupilumab is an example of a medication that targets IL-4.

 

Option D. IL-5: Mepolizumab and reslizumab are examples of medications that target IL-5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: A patient who was on antiepileptics for the management of seizure disorder started having visual disturbance. Evaluation reveals the contraction of the visual field. The drug responsible is likely to be? (AIIMS NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vigabatrin

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic that works by inhibiting GABA Transaminase. It is used for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is known to cause visual field constriction in some patients. This adverse effect is thought to be due to the drug's influence on the retina and the central nervous system. Vigabatrin is particularly associated with bilateral concentric visual field constriction, and patients on this medication are often monitored with regular visual field testing.

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenobarbitone: This is a barbiturate used to treat epilepsy, but it is not commonly associated with visual field defects. Its side effects may include sedation, dizziness, and cognitive changes, but not specifically visual disturbances like those described.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide: Primarily used for absence seizures, ethosuximide is not typically associated with visual field contractions. Its side effects can include gastrointestinal disturbances, drowsiness, and headaches.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: Commonly used in various forms of epilepsy, levetiracetam's side effects can include drowsiness, weakness, and behavioral changes, but it is not commonly associated with significant visual field disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug associated with visual field contraction, requiring regular monitoring of visual fields in patients receiving this medication.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria is erythromycin.

 

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that is effective against the bacteria that cause diphtheria. It is used to eradicate the bacteria from carriers and prevent the spread of the disease.
  • Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not the first-line treatment for diphtheria carrier state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin is the drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria due to its effectiveness in eradicating Corynebacterium diphtheriae from carriers and preventing the spread of the disease. Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not considered first-line treatments for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following drug acts at the site marked by arrow as shown in the diagram? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aliskiren

 

The arrow is marked at the step where Renin acts and helps in converting Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I. Angiotensin-I is converted to Angiotensin II with the help of Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE).
 

The drug Aliskiren is a direct competitive renin enzyme inhibitor. Other examples of Renin inhibitors include Remikiren, Enalkiren.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Ramipril: Is an ACE-Inhibitor. It inhibits the ACE enzyme which catalyze the conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II.

 

Option C. Losartan: Is an ARB (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker). It blocks the angiotensin receptor and inhibits its action of vasoconstriction and aldosterone release.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Is an Aldosterone blocker. It inhibits the action of Aldosterone of salt and water retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aliskiren acts at the step where renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, effectively inhibiting the renin enzyme and reducing the downstream effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This helps in managing hypertension by reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone-mediated sodium retention.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: The extent of drug absorption in plasma concentration vs time graph is represented by:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Area under the curve

 

Area under the curve (AUC) is a measure of the total drug exposure in the bloodstream over time. It reflects the total amount of drug absorbed and is often used to assess the overall bioavailability of a drug. AUC is crucial for determining the efficacy and safety of a medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax (Time to Maximum Concentration): Tmax represents the time it takes for a drug to reach its maximum concentration (Cmax) in the bloodstream. It tells about rate of drug absorption.

 

Option C. Cmax (Maximum Concentration): Cmax represents the highest concentration of a drug in the bloodstream after administration. This parameter is important because it indicates the peak therapeutic effect and helps assess the risk of side effects associated with high drug concentrations.

 

Option D. t1/2 (Half-Life): t1/2 is the time it takes for half of the drug to be eliminated from the bloodstream. It is not directly related to drug absorption but is essential in understanding how long a drug remains in the body and how often it needs to be administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph represents the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the total drug exposure over time and the overall bioavailability of the drug.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿C is more potent than A
﻿﻿﻿B is more potent than A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B is competitive antagonist

 

This questions tests the knowledge regarding two different things about dose response curve:

 

a. Potency and Efficacy: Remember, to take HELP whenever in doubt. It means Height of the curve tells about Efficacy (higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug is) and Left sidedness of the curve tells about Potency (Drugs with curves on left side are more potent than drugs with curve on right side)

 

b. Type of Inhibition: If the curve shifts parallelly to right, the drug is a competitive inhibitor, if it shifts down, the drug is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

What is given in graph: 

 

  • The DRC of drug B has shifted to the right of the DRC of drug A , although the height of the two curves is the same. On the other hand, Drug C has shifted the curve down.
  • Further height of curve in Drug A and B is same but more than Drug C.
  • Curve of Drug A is on most left followed by Drug C and then Drug B.

 

Inferences:

 

Therefore, the following inferences can be drawn from the given image:

 

  • The efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C
  • The Potency of Drug A > Drug C > Drug B
  • Drug B is a competitive inhibitor of Drug A
  • Drug C is a non-competitive inhibitor of Drug A

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efficacy: The height of the curve represents the efficacy of the drug. The higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug.

 

Potency: The position of the curve along the x-axis (left or right) indicates the potency. Drugs with curves on the left side are more potent than those on the right side.

 

Type of Inhibition

 

  • Competitive Inhibition: A competitive inhibitor will shift the dose-response curve to the right without changing the maximum effect (efficacy). This indicates that higher concentrations of the agonist can overcome the inhibition.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition: A non-competitive inhibitor will reduce the maximum effect (efficacy) of the agonist, causing a downward shift in the dose-response curve.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml

 

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase in PR interval

questions.text: What is the likely ECG changes noted with the use of new anti-tubercular drug bedaquiline: (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

The likely ECG change noted with the use of bedaquiline is QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including a specific type known as Torsades de Pointes. Monitoring of the QT interval is important during bedaquiline therapy, and caution is advised, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions or those taking other medications that can also prolong the QT interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in PR interval: An increase in the PR interval is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option C. ST segment elevation: ST segment elevation is not a typical ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option D. QRS widening: QRS widening is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

QT prolongation is a well-documented ECG change associated with the use of bedaquiline. It is one of the notable side effects of this drug.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with a history of advanced-stage colorectal cancer is being evaluated for a new chemotherapy regimen. The oncologist is considering drugs that would inhibit DNA synthesis as a part of her treatment. Which of the following drugs is a known inhibitor of DNA synthesis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-Mercaptopurine
